POD #1 from CABG x5 & MV repair.  Bronched in OR, UF 2L while on
   bypass.
   Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)
   Assessment:
   Received on milrinone, epi, levo for hemodynamic support.  Sedated on
   propofol & fent gtt.
   Action:
   Weaned epi off & milrinone down.  Titrated levo to maintain sbp >90 &
   map >60.  Started lasix gtt.  Propofol dc
   Response:
   Filling pressures unremarkable. Svo2 decreased to 30s w/turning and
   wake ups.  BP stable on levo. Starting to diurese from lasix gtt. Pt
   combative and uncooperative off prop. Hemodynamically unstable & had
   decreased oxygenation.  Versed gtt added, then versed changed to
   precedex.  Currently pt on fent/precedex and is calm.
   Plan:
   Maintain milrinone at current dose, ?shut off in am.  Wean levo as tol.
   Titrate lasix gtt for negative hourly balance.  Wean fent as tol. See
   below for vent.
   ? Pneumonia, bacterial, community acquired (CAP)
   Assessment:
   Positive gram stain from specimen sent from OR. Thick [**Location (un) 173**] colored
   secretions. Adventitious breath sounds. Poor oxygenation on cpap. Low
   grade temp.
   Action:
   CXR obtained. Started on iv cipro/zosyn. IV vanco extended past four
   doses.  Lavaged & suctioned. Pt required increased peep/sedation/fio2.
   Response:
   Initially remained w/low oxygenation despite above interventions. Given
   recruitment breaths, placed on AC.  Sedation changed and increased.
   Then oxygenation improved.
   Plan:
   Awaiting culture results. Draw vanco trough prior to am dose. Remain on
   10 peep tonight. Wean fio2 as tol. Cpap trial in am. ?bronch if fails
   cpap trial.

76-year-old woman with complex vascular history and known severe
   systolic CHF (EF 20%) transferred to ICU from [**Hospital Unit Name 4201**] yesterday in setting
   of tachycardia, fever, and concern for impending sepsis.  Initially
   appeared hypovolemic and initial brisk response to fluids (HR 130s
   100s) with only transient mild hypotension.  Evaluation for immediately
   life-threatening causes of sepsis has been reassuring with negative
   chest and abdomen CTs.  Cultures NGSF except yeast in urine.
   1)       d/c flagyl (negative C diff, improved exam)
   2)       continue other present ABX while awaiting cultures
   3)       follow blood cultures given endovascular grafts
   4)       control temperature, as tachycardia appears related now to
   temperature (see above)
   5)       begin slowly adding back in usual cardiac meds
   6)       her encephalopathy appears to be subacute and may related to
   infection, metabolic derangements, and other causes.  Follow
   clinically.  Improved somewhat today.
   7)       to floor
   8)       discussed in detail with her family yesterday (she is not able
   to converse):  she is DNR/DNI
   Sepsis without organ dysfunction
   Assessment:
   Open eyes to verbal stimuli, clearer this am,
   Action:
   Response:
   Plan:

: 64-year-old man with liver cirrhosis [**12-21**] NASH, DM, HTN, CHF EF 40%,
   CAD, Seizure disorder who p/w cough, fevers and CXR findings c/w PNA.
   .
   # PNA: CXR with new RML haziness, cough and low grade fever c/w PNA.
   Patient is not hypoxic. Patient resides in NH making him at risk for
   hospital acquired PNA. In addition, he has an aspiration risk.
   - Vanc, Azithro and Unasyn
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Patient appears dry on exam, hypernatremia is likely
   [**12-21**] vol de[** Location **]n [**12-21**] poor free water intake and daily lasix. Pt
   received NS in the ED
   - obtain urine lytes
   - stop NS
   - reassess chem 7 and consider free water in tube feeds
   .
   # Limited mental status: Per family, pt is at baseline. Ammonia level
   not particularly elevated although the patient does have clonus on
   exam. PNA, fever and multiple anticonvulsants may be contributing. He
   does not appear encephalopathic
   .
   # Hx Cirrhosis: s/p TIPS, not transplant candidate. LFT's are
   unremarkable. MELD score 5.
   - cont rifamixin and lactulose
   .
   # Hx CHF: systolic dysfunction with EF 40%, BNP equivocal but pt not
   volume overloaded on exam. No acute exacerbation. As pt is currently
   vol depleted and hypernatremic will hold lasix for time being
   - hold lasix
   - cont Metoprolol
   .
   # hx Seizures:
   - cont keppra, topomax and zonisamide
   .
   # Hx  DM: NH records are diffucult to read re lantus dosing but wife
   reports that his lantus dose has been recently reduced since last
   discharge
   - will prescribe lantus 20 qhs
   - SSI
   .
   # Hx hypothyroidism
   - cont levothyroxine 400mg daily
   - check TSH, FT4
   .
   #) Prophylaxis: PPI, sc heparin, bowel regimen
   .
   #) FEN: TF and NPO for now given ? of aspiration
   .
   #) Access: PIVs
   .
   #) Code Status: Full
   .
   #) Dispo: pending further work-up and treatment
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale

d for sml amounts of blood tinged secretions (MD

TITLE:
   Diabetes Mellitus (DM), Type I
   Assessment:
   Insulin gtt for glycemic control, Pt trending upwards during beginning
   of night then trending down in early am.  Pt taking g-ale, no a[** Location **]e.
   Action:
    [**Last Name (un) 257**]  sliding scale followed, D10 @ 20cc/hr since no PO intake
   secondary to nausea. Ativan , Zofran, Reglan, Zyprex for nausea
   control.
   Response:
   BS 37-270.  nausea appearing  to be well controlled overnight, this am
   pt dry heaving and vomited a sm amt of  phlegm up.
   Plan:
   Continue to titrate insulin gtt per protocol, continue anti-enemics and
   encourage PO intake, ? restart insulin pump.today.
   Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
   Assessment:
   A/ox3, neuro exam remains intact, pt denies numbness and tingling in
   extremities PERRLA  3mm/brisk. Describes HA as [**2754-4-30**]. Diplopia
   persists, though pt says it has gradually been improving each day.
   Action:
   Dilaudid and Fiorocet given overnight for pain control. Neuro exam
   followed Q2.
   Response:
   Pain  well controlled per pt , though pt stoic at times.
   Plan:
   Angio on Wed to r/o vasospasm or bleeding, consider changing neuro
   exams to Q4, notify team of any changes. Encourage pain meds ATC.
   Hypovolemia (Volume De[** Location **]n - without shock)
   Assessment:
   BP dropped to 79/50 while asleep, pt was found to be diaphoretic during
   this time (as his blood glucose had dropped to 37and had since
   increased to 110)
   Action:
   1L NS fluid bolus given. NS with 20meqK at 50cc/hr continues as maint.
   Fluids.
   Response:
   BP immediately responded to fluid challenge , BP  back to baseline of
   100
   Plan:
   Monitor BP and considering  incessable losses consider increasing
   maint. fluids

Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   Assessment:
   Pt presents with acute respiratory failure from rehab, chest X-Ray
   showed large right sided pleural effusion.
   Lung sounds rhonchorous throughout, very diminished to Right side.
   Pt is lethargic, in respiratory distress at times.
   Action:
   Placed on CPAP mask in ED.
   Given Morphine and Haldol for distress.
   Started on triple antibiotic coverage for effusion.
   Response:
   Pt able to settle out and tolerate mask.
   ABG shows continued respiratory acidosis.
   Unable to tap effusion as pt
s INR 3 due to warferin for A-fib.
   Plan:
   Family aware of poor prognosis, plan is to keep pt comfortable as long
   as can tolerate CPAP mask.  They are aware that pt will need to come
   off mask in next 12hrs or so due to breakdown risk

45 yo M w/ PMH significant for recurrent Hodgkin's lymphoma s/p auto &
   allo transplant, on monthly chemotherapy admitted after presenting to
   Onc clinic on [**8-14**] febrile to 101.  CXR at that time revealed an
   evolving RLL /LUL infiltrate. He was admitted for further evaluation
   with CXR and CT chest concerning for evolving pneumonia. Started on
   broad specturm abx, however became mildly hypotensive to 80
s while on
   7F which was fluid responsive.  Admitted to M/SICU on [**8-17**] for elective
   bronch, post procedure became persistently hypotensive/tachy w/ HR 140
   1600 pt c/o nausea, requesting for Lorazepam, 0.5 mg IV given with good
   effect
   .H/O alkalosis, respiratory
   Assessment:
   At start of shift, RR  shallow in 30
s, maintaining sats of 98-99% on
   2liters O2 NC, LS with scattered rhonchi in L upper and lower lobes and
   diminished in R lower lobe, pt appears comfortable. Occasional dry non
   productive cough noted.  Blood gases this a.m 7.38/ 36/116. Pt alert
   and oriented x2.
   Action:
   O2 decreased to 1 liter/min , continued to monitor resp status,
   scheduled inhalers and nebs given , xray chest obtained.
   Response:
   Good response to decreased O2, maintaining sats around 93-94%, no s/sx
   of respiratory distress noted, pt says
I feel much better than
   yesterday)
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor resp state with low O2 considering bleomycin
   toxicity, ? try to wean off O2 as tolerated, follow up with  BAL
   reports.
   .H/O sepsis without organ dysfunction
   Assessment:
   Afebrile,  A/Ox2., WBC 7.3 up from 3.3, BUN 18, Creat 1.0, Lactic acid
   1.1
   Action:
   Continued on antibiotics, vitals monitored
   Response:
   Remains afebrile,   mentating well with good [**Month/Day (4) **] output.
   Plan:
   Continue on antibiotics, monitor mental status, follow up on  cultures

   Assessment:
   BP in low 90
s systolic, MAP around 55, pt mentating well A/o x2, U/O

Altered mental status (not Delirium)
   Assessment:
   Much more oriented than 24 hrs ago, still confused to date at times and
   place. Speech no longer garbled and is able to state needs clearly.
   Follows simple commands, opens mouth. Became agitated with bath and
   yelled out throughout entire bath but calmed down  when finished. Pt
   also requesting lax and supp to move bowels.
   Action:
   Reoriented pt to place and time. Allowed to rest throughout the shift.
    Reminded pt that she would not be able to walk independantly until
   healed.
   Response:
   Pt stating that she is able to walk with walker. Not remembering where
   she is but does remember nurses name easily. Mental status is clearing.
   Plan:
   Cont to reorient pt and remind her of limitations. Remind pt of the
   importance of turning in bed. Update son on any changes which occur. Pt
   is a potential call out to the floor.
   Renal failure, acute (Acute renal failure, ARF)
   Assessment:
   Bun and creat are currently pending. u/o low but urine is yellow with
   some sediment. Pt has generalized edema. Cvp 13-16. pt is now taking in
   some po and drinking without difficulty.
   Action:
   Cont to monitor u/o and bun/creat. Pt has a fistula but renal team is
   trying to avoid hd so pt will regain enough kidney function on own.
   Response:
   Pt is drinking, acidosis is corrected.
   Plan:
   Cont to monitor kidney function and u/o. observe for increased edema.
   Encourage po intake.

54 year-old female with history of alcohol abuse, status post
   splenectomy, status post multiple abdominal surgeries initially
   presenting with altered mental status, dyspnea, and abdominal pain. The
   patient has been complaining of poorly localized abdominal pain over
   the past few weeks. The patient's mother states that the patient had
   been on an alcohol binge for a few days without significant PO intake.
   The mother was checking on her the day prior to admission because the
   patient
was having a bad day
 (not able to further characterize) and
   early this morning found the patient complaining of difficulty
   breathing. The patient subsequently became confused and was not
   responding appropriately to questions. The mother called EMS to bring
   the patient to the ED, and she was noted to be obtunded in the
   ambulance.
   On arrival to the ED at 04:23, vitals were T 96.9 HR 121 BP 82/48 RR 20
   SaO2 99%RA, FSG 18. The patient was given at least 2 amps D50, as well
   as thiamine 100 mg IV 40 minutes later with improvement in mental
   status. At 07:20, the patient complained of fatigue/malaise with her
   nurse in the room and subsequently became unresponsive. The patient was
   asystolic. During the code the patient received epinephrine x 7,
   atropine x 3, calcium x 2, magnesium x 2, narcan x 2. A femoral line
   was placed and the patient was given 2-4L of saline. She was coded for
   26 minutes, with final return of a perfusing rhythm with pulses 07:56.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   [**Name (NI) **] pt off of pressors, MAPs >60. HR low 100s in NST, no ectopy.
   Action:
   Pt cont on Arctic Sun protocol, keeping body temp at 34.0 c. Q4H lytes
   and ABGs sent.  Pt on Fentanyl and Versed gtt
s for comfort while being
   cooled.
   Response:

   HPI:
   Ms [**Known patient lastname 3927**] is a 75F with a PMH s/f subglottic edema from multiple
   intubations, HTN, DM, and ESRD, who was found unresponsive at her
   nursing home today.  Per the patient's daughter and nurse [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (NI) 429**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], she had been in her USOH, which included mild stridor since her
   recent discharge from [**Hospital1 52**].  Starting on Sunday ([**6-27**]), her daughter
   noticed she seemed more "out of breath" than usual.  She was started on
   albuterol/ipratropium with good effect.  On Wednesday [**6-30**] the patient
   became acutely uncomfortable, complaining that something was "stuck in
   her throat".  She was noted to be restless, stridorous, and clutching
   her throat at the time.  She was given a one-time dose of benadryl, and
   suddenly dropped her O2 sats to 87% on 6L NC, became unresponsive and
   "limp".  She maintained a pulse throughout.  EMS was called and the
   patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 52**]. Of note, the patient was stopped on
   lisinopril/valsartan on her last admission for concern that angioedema
   may have contributed to her stridor.  She was restarted on valsartan on
   [**6-28**] when her symptoms worsenened.
   .
   In the emergency department the patient was afebrile, SBPs ranged from
   198-240, HR in the 50s, RR 15.  She was started on a labetalol drip for
   hypertension.  She was intubated for airway protection and was noted to
   have a difficult airway.  Serum tox, cardiac enzymes, CBC were all
   wnl.  A head CT, CXR, CT neck and torso were completed and were all
   grossly wnl, except for a non-perfusing left vertebral artery.  She was
   given 1g of CTX, 1g of vancomycin, and 500mg of metronidazole despite
   not having fevers, leukocytosis or any focal signs of infection.  She
   was pan cultured.  She was noted to have coffee ground emesis through
   her OG tube, with guiac negative stools, and was given 40mg of IV
   pantoprazole.
   To MICU for further monitoring and work-up. Remains on labetalol gtt

78 yo man who was recently discharged from [**Hospital 112**] Hospital following
   a fall.  There he was worked up for head trauma and syncope. A EKG
   revealed RBBB and LAFB.  He has a PMH of anemia. His hct at time was
   20.7 and he was treated with 2uprbc. CT of his head showed no acute
   intracranial pathology. CXR revealed rsome increased markings on his
   left side  felt to be atelectsis vs pna he had no s+s of pna.  He was
   discharged after two days, records unavailable at present time.  The
   patient stated that he has had worsening right sided pain the radiates
   to his chest, since discharge from hospital.  Worse with inspiration.
   No fevers, chills or diaphoresis. He presented to pcp with [**Name Initial (PRE) **] BP 80/p
   and brought to ED. CXR showed low lung volumes on right. CT chest
   showed effusion on right with mild ascites. He received vanco,
   levofloxacin  and azreonam for suspected right sided pna. He also
   received 2liters NS and 1liter of D5W with 3amp of bicarb. The patient
   was seen by interventional pulmonary who performed a ultrasounded
   thoracentesis during which 1200cc of serosanginous fluid was drained.
   The  initial pH 7.08, pleural LDH of 468 indicative of an exudative
   process and a pigtail catheter was placed.
   PMH significant for myelofibrosis, anemia, Zenker
s diverticulum.
   Significant macula degeneration and cataracts making him legally blind,
   depression, Pruritis, mild symmetric LVH, moderate pulmonary HTN
   Pneumonia, aspiration
   Assessment:
   Pt had speech and swallow done and failed.   Pt states that he always
   has trouble swallowing and coughs after each time he eats.  O2 at 2L
   via NC.
   Action:
   Discussion with pt regarding options of care at this point.   Pt has
   been refusing any treatment  for diverticulum and wants to continue on
   with the way he has been tolerating the swallowing issues.   Medical
   resident attempted to have discussion with pt about DNR/DNI
 after
   repeated conversations
 it became clear that pt was not fully
   comprehending the questions.    Pt states that he does not know what to
   do.   He is worried about the risk of death if he repairs the
   diverticulum and when informed that he takes a risk each time he eats,
   - he states that he wants to stay in the middle somewhere.   He does
   not appear to understand the severity of the situation.   MICU team
   questioning cause of pleural effusion and plan to work with IP to
   acquire a specimen from the pigtail to check for possible malignancies
   or other causes.
   Response:

Ms. [**Known patient lastname 8703**] is a 71 y.o. woman  with a pmh of COPD and MR, who
   presented to the ED on the morning of admission with on day of
   intractable vomiting. The pt reports that for the last 12-24 hours she
   has been nauseated and vomiting yellowish, non-bloody material. She
   denies associated symptoms such as abdominal pain, CP, fever, chills.
   She believes she last moved her bowels this morning.
   On arrival, initial vitals were HR 118, 155/109, RA O2 sat 88%. She was
   placed on NIPPV briefly and her oxygenation improved. Labs were
   remarkable for a polycythemia (HCT 63) and lactate of 2.3, later noted
   to rise to 4.1 (question spurious sample) before falling to 3.0 in the
   setting of 9L NS fluid re[** Location **]n. A CT scan of her abdomen was
   performed and demonstrated a high grade SBO with a transition point in
   the region of distal jejunum/proximal ileum, as well as a question of a
   pulmonary infarct. The pt was emperically treated with vancomycin,
   Flagyl, levofloxacin, SoluMedrol, ASA and antiemetics. The surgery
   service was consulted concerning this and advised NGT placement,
   supportive therapy and close clinical observation, as they feel she is
   a poor operative candidate. The hematology service was also consulted
   concerning the pt's polycytemia and advised ASA, fluids and therepeutic
   phlebotomy which was performed with 340cc of blood removed.
   On arrival to the [**Hospital Unit Name 42**], the pt is generally comfortable. She reports
   some ongoing nausea but again denies abdominal pain. She states she
   feels her breathing is at her baseline.

[**Age over 90 **] y/o Russian speaking woman with history of paroxysmal afib (not on
   coumadin), CHF (EF 40-45% [**3169**]), who was admitted on [**3-28**] after being
   found down in her home. Evaluation in the ED showed a RML pneumonia and
   a new oxygen requirement of approximately 4 L. She was admitted to the
   floor when the day after admission she developed atrial fibrillation
   with RVR. Initially rate controlled was attempted with with IV
   metoprolol followed by IV diltiazem.  After about 18 hours, she
   converted to NSR. At this time plan was to titrate up home metoprolol
   and start po diltiazem. However, her cardiologist was contact[**Name (NI) **] and
   recommended discontinuing the diltiazem and up titrating the metoprolol
   to simplify her regimen. The diltiazem was then discontinued on
   [**3171-3-30**]. This morning patient went into Afib with RVR rates 130.  She
   became increasingly hypoxic requiring 50% face mask (ABG
   7.43/35/64/24).  She was given diltiazem 10 mg IV x 2 with improvement
   in her rate to < 100.  With rate control her oxygen demand decreased to
   96% on 6L NC.  She was continued on face mask, however, for comfort.
   Due to systolic blood pressures in the 90s the primary team and nursing
   staff was hesitant to give lasix.  The decision was made to transfer to
   the ICU for further rate control management and diuresis.
   Slightly confused overnight, not tolerating face tent; EKG done prior
   to giving one time dose haldol, but not given as pt settled on her own.

   differentiated adenocarcinoma .  A staging CT scan at that time was
   negative for metastasis.  He had a CEA of 1.3 back in [**2703**] and then
   underwent adjuvant 5-FU with leucovorin beginning in [**2704-3-29**] through
   [**2704-8-29**].  He completed 6 cycles of this chemotherapy.  Mr.
   [**Known patient lastname 1223**] had a surveillance colonoscopy on [**2705-1-11**], which revealed more
   than 10 mixed non-bleeding polyps throughout his entire colon.  These
   were found to be adenomas by pathology and he subsequently underwent
   subtotal colectomy on [**2705-6-13**]. He underwent surgery on [**2709-5-11**]
   and had an extended right hepatic lobectomy, cholecystectomy and
   extensive lysis of adhesions.  The specimen within the liver revealed
   metastatic, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with
   colon primary.  Started chemotherapy [**9-6**] with Xeloda and Oxaliplatin.

   There was no witnessed seizure activity.  He was not complaining of
   chest pain, SOB, palpitations, abdominal pain or nausea prior to the
   fall. Per the patient's wife he has not been recently ill.  EMS was
   called and he was brought to [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 76**].  At the OSH he was found to
   have slowed speech and confusion.  He complained of right hip pain.  A
   head CT was attempted and in the scanner the patient had witnessed
   vomiting, aspiration and respiratory arrest.  He was intubated.  CXR
   showed bilateral infiltrates and he was given levo/flagyl and vanco.
   He also received morphine 2mg, etomodate, versed 1mg x3 and 3L IVF.

62 yo M with h/o of multiple MVAs over the past 1 year and subsequently
   residing in a nursing home  found unresponsive in vomitus and asystolic
   this morning, apenic and cyanotic, he had made some gasping efforts.
   He was seen 10 minutes earlier and in no distress and at baseline.
   Apparently nursing staff noted him to be apenic and placed an AED which
   advised "no shock" and called EMS.  By EMS he was noted to be in a PEA
   arrest with a narrow complex tachycardia at a rate of around 100.  He
   was given epi and atropine x 2 doses each.  He never regained a pulse
   during his transport.  By the time he arrived at [**Hospital3 **] he was
   again noted to be in PEA arrest with a rate of 170-180 with occasional
   triplets of PVCs.  He was given 1mg of epi, 1 amp of bicarb and 1g of
   magnesium (for the ectopy) and he regained a pulse with a SBP of 100.
   His perfusing rhythm was atrial fibrillation with a rate of 120 with
   reportedly no ischemic changes on his EKG.
   .
   The patient had been intubated in the field and in the ER there had
   been vomitus in the ET tube.  The patient was initially vented at AC
   500 x 14 with a PEEP of 5 and FiO2 of 100%.  His ABG on this was 7.1 /
   52 / 510.  At this point his FiO2 was decreased to 40%, a CXR revealed
   some scarring at the R base of the patient's lung, also the ET tube was
   at the carina and was pulled back 2 cm. In transport with [**Location (un) 1038**],
   had another arrest, diverted briefly to [**Hospital6 **], where
   pulse was regained. Total downtime on second arrest approx 30 mins.
   .

TITLE: Nursing Student Progress Note 7-3pm
   The pt is a 63y.o. F with a PMH of metastatic non small cell Lung CA
   admitted with acute respiratory distress. The pt was found to have an
   abrupt episode of respiratory distress this am while at home. EMS was
   called by her son and pt was found to be unresponsive. On arrival to
   the ED the patient was intubated. Reports by ED, difficulty passing ET
   tube. Following intubation the pt lost a pulse. No strips available. ED
   reports probable PEA arrest. She received atropine and epinephrine and
   CPR started with restoration of perfusing rhythm. ECG per report
   demonstrated 2mm anterior ST elevations and Code STEMI called.
   Cardiology evaluated and felt not consistent with ACS. Bedside TTE
   performed showing no effusion and no focal wall motion abnormality. CXR
   consistent with left lung collapse. CTA negative for PE. Pt started on
   phenyephrine for SBP 63. HCT found to be 20 and pt given 1U PRBC.
   Femoral line placed. CT Abd/pelvis completed with [** Location **] read negative
   for bleed. IP consulted in the ED for L lung collapse.
   Events: Bronchoscopy 1030 am showed expansion of LL, US and
   thoracentesis drained 850 cc serosanguinous fluid.

   Assessment:
   Pt tachycardic/ AFib with HR 80-129.

   EKG obtained, IV amiodarone discontinued, PO amiodarone started 400mg
   PO q12hour.  Pt also started on SC lovenox q12hour.

   After PO amiodarone pt converted to NSR with frequent PVCs and

   Continue to monitor telemetry, check lytes, replete as needed, continue

   acute cardiopulmonary process. He was satting 87% on room air prior to
   transfer. With 3L O2 by NC, sats came up to 95%. Vitals prior to
   transfer 96.2ax 72 118/78 24.
   .
   On arrival to our ED, he was started on bipap after his DNR/DNI status
   was confirmed with patient and HCP. His [**Name2 (NI) **] were notable for a
   leukocytosis and ARF (no priors for comparison). Once Bipap was
   initiated, his sats responded well, however, he became hypotensive
   (100/50 -> 80 with starting bipap). He was given 2L NS, then levophed

   Blood cultures were drawn. On transfer, his pulse 70, BP 99/70, RR 20,

s with MAP

not sure what

73 F w/ pmh of pulmonary fibrosis (not on prednisone) presented to
   [**Hospital1 594**] w/ 3 days of SOB (per family) and fever (per patient).
   Initially 87% on a NRB.  Put on CPAP and is much more comfortable.
   Febrile to 103.  EKG changes initially resolved and elevated trop.
   Thought to be at risk for both CHF and pneumonia so treated with
   levoflox 500 mg IV, lasix 80 mg IV,  prior to tx.  Labs at [**Hospital1 594**] w/
   BNP of 14,000, Cr of 1.8, and trop of 1.2.  Started on a nitro ggt for
   SBP of 160s at [**Hospital1 594**].  Arrived in our ED w/ SBP in the 80s, still on a
   nitro ggt.
   In the ED, initial vs were: T 102 P 105-->85 BP 92 --> 85 (Nitro ggt
   turned off) SBP now 90/66. R 35 --> 29 O2 sat 99% on 100% FiO2 on
   CPAP.  Patient was given ASA 600 pr, tylenol 650 pr.  Pt received 2L NS
   here and has had 100 cc urine since arrival at [**Hospital1 594**].
   After arrival into MICU, pt was on CPAP and weaned to 50% HiFlow mask.
   BP marginal and given 500cc FB and  250cc FB x4. LENIS were negative.
   Labs were concerning for DIC, LFTs elevated.  An a-line was placed. ABG
   was obtained showing metabolic acidosis. Pt
s  Cr cont to rise to 2.8.
   K rising to 5.0. Pt had episode of 20 beat run Vtach. Pt BP remained
   labile despite fluids and was not making any urine. Given her poor resp
   status and renal failure, the pt needed  vasopressors and central line.
   Pt was unable to lay flat in bed [**1-14**] her poor resp status for safe line
   placement. The pt had become more anxious and restless, and it was not
   possible to give her any sedating meds [**1-14**] to hypotension. Intubation
   was discussed multiple times and at length with the patient and her
   daughter. The pt remained firm that no matter the outcome, she did not
   want to be intubated and wanted to go to sleep. The decision was made
   to make the pt comfortable. The pt was given 0.5mg IV Ativan x3 with
   poor effect. Pt was then given 2mg IV Morphine, still with poor effect.
   Pt was given an additional 3mg IV Morphine and was then started on
   Morphine IV gtt at 2.0mg/hr.

   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] from [**Hospital3 **] ICU (per his family's request). The
   patient presented to [**Hospital3 **] ED on [**3133-4-26**] with generalized
   weakness, fever to 103F, lethargy, dyspnea, and was noted to have an
   oxygen saturation in the 70s on RA (no prior oxygen requirement). He
   denied N/V/D, abdominal pain, change in urinary habits, but did endorse
   orthopnea. He was admitted to the [**Hospital3 **] ICU for severe
   respiratory failure. CXR at that time showed evidence of bilateral
   pneumonia (thought to be aspiration), and he was noted to have a
   leukocytosis of 14. Despite initial treatment with IV ceftriaxone,
   azithromycin, and solumedrol, the patient was unable to tolerate taper
   off nonrebreather and required BiPAP to help maintain oxygen
   saturations. Given that he appeared worse both clinically and by xray,
   antibiotics were switched to levaquin, vanc, and zosyn. Concern was
   also raised for fluid overload contributing to his respiratory failure,
   so he was diuresed with 20 mg IV lasix x 1 with good [**Name (NI) **] (pt fluid
   status +600cc at time of transfer). An initial sputum culture and blood
   cultures x2 at the OSH were negative.  A repeat sputum culture, urine
   Legionella, and mycoplasma serology were done at the OSH and are
   pending at the time of transfer.
   .
   The patient has no history of COPD or CHF. Per his daughter, he has
   never had an echo. He had a pneumovax in [**3131**] and influenza vaccine in
   [**3132**].
   .
   On the floor, initial vs were: BP 148/74, P 111, RR 33, with an
   O2sat of 95% on CPAP 80%FiO2 and 8 PEEP. ABG was reassuring at
   7.42/36/84.
   .

75 y/o F hx CAD with ischemic cardiomyopathy s/p ICD, HTN, DM, CVA now

   on [**3-20**] with black tarry stools since Sunday. She also had N and coffee

   arthritis pain. She was also c/o weakness and fatigue. She denied any
   CP, palpitations, BRBPR, hemetemesis, fevers.

   At OSH, initial HCT was 18 although she was hemodynamically stable with
   BPs in 100's. R fem line was placed in OSH ED. NG lavage revealed
   yellow clear fluid with speckles of blood clots. She received
   sandostatin 100 mcg/hr, FFP X 2, 1U plts, and 6U PRBCs. EGD at [**Hospital1 1211**]
   revealed some small esophageal varices and evidence of portal HTN
   gastropathy. No ulcers were seen. Also, Pt was found to have troponins
   which peaked at 18, CKMB 9. Creatinine was 1.5. Abd U/S revealed trace

   were negative.

   pain. She had been at Foxwoods and did not wish to leave which is why
   she waited 2 days to go to hospital. She reports that 10 yrs ago she
   had one episode of dark emesis and was told she had a bowel

s wife
   called 911; EMS noted pt cyanotic, hypoxic to 89%.  ED CXR revealed RLL
   infiltrate.  PMH includes HTN, hyperlipidemia, CAD, anterior MI in
   s/p angioplasty, IDDM (pt admits to dietary non-compliance), spinal
   stenosis, s/p L2-L5 laminectomies and multiple medication allergies
   with several episodes of severe hives.
   Of note the patient has been treated with dicloxacillin for the last 10
   days for a LLE injury that became infected.  He developed a rash prior
   to starting the antibiotics that was located on his back, chest and
   arms.  The patient nor wife can recall any change that could cause the
   rash but do note that the patient does frequently have rashes that
   occur for no clear reason.
   In the ED the patient was given levofloxacin and then found to have BP
   of 80s.  IV fluids were given and the patient responded with BP.
   Additionally, the patient was given Vancomycin.  The patient and wife
   report that he immediately broke out in hives and became "red",
   experienced episode of vomitting.  Rec
d solumedrol, benadryl and
   pepcid with improvement in the rash.  He was placed on a NRB prior to
   transport.
   .
   On arrival to the floor the patient was asymptomatic.  Eyes swollen but
   rash improving.

posterior left ventricular branch artery via collaterals.

left ventricular branch artery and the obtuse marginal

    78F on ASA and Plavix tripped on rug and bumped into a wall.  One hour

   surgery from basal cell removal w/ excellent effect). Urine output
   slowed after com[** Location **]n of IVF (patient volume status positive for
   admission- will need lasix in am). Right groin site dry and intact
   overnight. No s/s tamponade. 9 pm labs (electrolytes, platelets, HCT
   and CK) are wnl.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor for c/o CP or SOB. Continue to monitor right groin
   site and swan tracing to ensure RA waveform. Team plans to diurese with
   lasix in the am (held overnight [**2-14**] large dye load in cath lab). Likely
   remove swan catheter this am after echo to ensure no tamponade.
   Continue smoking cessation counseling and support.

76yo female while at home was sitting eating ice cream and
   developed and acute constant pain behind her right eye that
   migrated down right lateral posterior neck. She then froze and
   shook a little bit. She continued to c/o severe right headache
   and was noted to have a left facial droop. She proceeded to pass
   out. She was then lowered to the floor, EMS called, transported
   to OSH where CT imaging of the brain revealed a large SAH, IVH.
   Transferred to [**Hospital1 17**] for further Neurosurgical evaluation.
   Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
   Assessment:
   Pt intubated, arouses to pain. pt withdrawls extremities to all nailbed
   pressure, does not open eyes. Pupils uneven at times R 2-3 mm, L [**4-4**]
   mm. No signs/symptoms of pain. ICP 5-9. R sided vent drain 15 cm at
   tragus, bloody drainage noted. On CMV tidal volumes RR 12, PEEP 5.
   Lungs CTA all lobes posteriorly, O2 sats 98%.
   Action:
   Q2 hr neuro checks, monitor ICP, monitor drain output, maintain pt
   safety
   Response:
   Slightly improved neuro status from start of shift
 pt withdrawls to
   pain.
   Plan:
   Continue to assess neuro status q 2.

58yr old male with known CAD. s/p PCIs after anterior MI in [**2686**].  New
   angina & L arm discomfort with exertion.  Cath showed 3VD, pt referred
   for csurg.
   s/p CABG x4 today.  Report received from anesthesia. Uneventful OR.
   Arrived in CVICU in SR, on prop/neo/ins gtt, Normothermic. Same day
   admit, pt received cefazolin in OR.
   Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)
   Assessment:
   Stable post-op.  Candidate for fast track wean.
   Action:
   Post op CXR and EKG obtained. CXR reviewed by NP.  Neo/nitro gtts used
   to maintain sbp 90-120. Lytes sent/repleted. Insulin gtt titrated per
   cvicu protocol.  Pt reversed & propofol gtt shut off. IVP morphine
   admin for assumed pain.
   Response:
   Awake, following simple commands, MAE. Pt placed on cpap 5/5 50%.
   Continues to be in SR. On nitro gtt for hypertension once sedation shut
   off. CT drainage increased w/hypertension.
   Plan:
   Plan to follow ABG. Wean to extubate as tol. Maintain sbp 90-120
   overnight. Monitor CT output. Advance per csurg protocol.

Received the pt intubated with Rt IJ central line and Rt fem A line.Pt
   maxed out on Neo, levophed and vasopressin.BP in 70
s systolic.
   Multiple FB given for a total of #lit over one hr.
   Pt bradying down to 50
s Gave total of  2mg Atropine. HR Transiently
   up,BP down to 60
s systolic, added dopamine.Had total of 4amps of
   bicarb, 3amps of calcium, and 2mg epinephrine.BP trending down and HR
   trending down.CPR started for a brief period.Family was called and the
   attending spoke to his wife on the phone.She said she would not be able
   to come in.Pt
s aunt  in and spoke to the attending.
   Pt was pronounced dead at [**2608**].Aunt came to see pt and wife was called
   re the event.Family wanted autopsy and Medical examiner was consulted
   by the team.Catholic priest was called as per aunt
s request and he
   said he would pray for him during the am mass.

66YO male POD4 CABG X 4 [**12-16**]
   Off gtts, chest tubes out, wires out.
   .H/O dementia (including Alzheimer's, Multi Infarct)
   Assessment:
   Pt oriented to self and place in AM. Does not know DOB, has trouble
   focusing on questions being asked by staff
   Action:
   Speak slowly and talk about one issue at a time. Keep stimuli to a
   minimum in the room. Wife stays in the room all the time
   Response:
   Pt responds well to one on one interaction with RN. Consistency with
   staff helps. Wife to stay throughout day, pt responds well to her when
   he get worked up and aggravated with staff.
   Plan:
   Transfer to [**Hospital Ward Name **] 6 private room
   Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)
   Assessment:
   Pt reports back pain when back in bed.
   Action:
   Given 2mg Dilaudid PO, repositioned back to chair, back rub
   Response:
   Reports improvement with back pain
   Plan:
   Assess pain level and ask specific questions regarding pain and types.
   Does better answering specific questions.

82M Cantonese speaking only who was brought by "the ride" to his outpt
   HD treatment today. Once checked in, pt noted to have wt up 6kg from
   baseline, RR 38, dyspnea, and hypertension to sbp 180's. Ambulance
   called, pt was administered 3 nitro tablets and lasix en route to
   [**Hospital1 1**]. Placed on BIPAP in EW for SOB and O2 sats in high 80's on NRB.
   Pt then fatigued and was intubated. Transferred to MICU for stat HD and
   for further management.
   Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   Assessment:
   Intubated, AC 500 x 12, +5, 40%. Breath sounds clear, Occ 1-3 breaths
   over rate on propofol gtt.
   Action:
   Labetolol given via OGT prior to extubation as BP 140s-150s/ on45 mcg
   propofol. ABG 7.42/58/79/39.  Propofol gtt shut off, pt  eyes open,
   following commands, extubated to 40% FT @ 2200. I/E wheezes after
   extubation, alb/atr nebs x 2
   Response:
   Wheezes cleared after nebs. No resp distress. RR teens, sats 96-97%.

   delerious/agitated. Pt. would initially follow commands but was easily

   large bilateral SAH

   3L NS IVF, with improvement of his SBP to the 90s and in his mental
   status. CT-Abdomen/Pelvis showed extensive ascites, shrunken liver,
   diffuse colonic wall thickening sparing sigmoid concerning for
   infectious.
   Within minutes of diagnostic paracentesis com[** Location **]n, patient suffered
   from large-volume hematemesis. Oropharynx suctioned of approx 750cc
   bright red blood. Attending interventionalist and hepatology team
   notified. Packed RBCs and FFP initiated. Urgently intubated by
   anesthesia. Octreotide and Protonix gtts initiated as well. Shortly
   after intubation, pt developed dusky neck tissue with concern for
   subcutaneous emphysema. CXR showed no evidence of such, but did reveal
   new patchy infiltrates bilaterally, suggesting aspiration of blood.
   Urgent right femoral line was placed. Given continued hematemesis of
   small amounts (totalling approximately 3000cc), PRBCs and FFP were
   continued. The hepatology team arrived for emergent endoscopy. EGD
   showed blood in the esophagus and multiple varices, but due to
   continued bleeding and poor visualization despite aspiration of blood,
   a [**State 1470**] ([**Last Name (un) 461**]) tube was placed.

The patient is a 23 year old female with significant past medical
   history who presented with complaints of myagilas and fevers for 2 days
   duration.  She had initially presented to her PCPs office with these
   complaints.  She described temperatures to 101 at home, with associated
   diffue body pains, but more focused back pain (L > R.)  Her symptoms
   started with dysuria and polyuria.  She has not experiencieced any
   abdomial pain, nausea/vomiting, diahrea, neck stiffness, headaches or
   confusion.  She has not had any vaginal discharge or any new sexual
   encounters.  She was found to be tachycardic to the 130s and reffered
   to the ED.
   .
   In the ED, initial VS:  T 103.4, HR 136, BP 130/84, RR 18, satting 100%
   on RA.  She was initially given 4 L of NS, with improvement of HRs to
   the 100s. .  With a UA c/w a UTI, she was given a dose of
   ciprofloxacin, with plans to observe overnight.  She again spike to
   103.5, with HRs up to 170s, but otherwise hemodynamcially stable.
   Repeat blood cultures were drawn, and a dose of CTX was additionally
   given.  Demerol was given for rigors.  She was given a total of 5L of
   NS.  The patient was admitted to the MICU for further management.
   Urinary tract infection (UTI)
   Assessment:
   Given the complaints of dysuria, + CVA tenderness, and + UA, most
   likely cause is a urinary tract infection.  No evidence of renal
   dysfunction to suggest obstructive uropathy.  Blood cutlures currently
   pending.  No evidence of infectious infiltrate on CXR and nothing in
   clinical history to suggest meningitis or abdominal pathology.
   Upon arrival to unit temp 100.2 with HR 130-140
s, ST, BP stable, no
   c/o of chills, but whole bode aching
   Action:
   Given clonipin for anxiety, start NS at 250cc/hr for 2L
   Response:
   Temp down to 98.7. pt voids clear urine. HR down to 118-120
   Plan:
   Cont follow temp, possible c/o tomorrow

Patient is an 84 y/o F with history of HTN, dementia, TTP, CKD admitted
   to the ICU for hypoxia. Per the patients husband, she complained of
   feeling tired in the morning, and then around noon felt generally
   unwell and short of breath. The patient was brought to the nurse at the
   independent living facility where her and her husband live; there she
   was found to have low oxygen saturation, and, per the family, an
   irregular heart rate. In general, she denies fevers, chills, shortness
   of breath. She reported some pain in her right ankle the day prior to
   admission. denies calf pain, abdominal pain, nausea vomitting.
   She was taken initially to [**Hospital3 **] where her D-dimer was
   negative, CXR with no focal infiltrate, negative VQ scan, and she was
   afebrile. The family requested she be transferred to [**Hospital1 17**], as most of
   her other care is here.

   BP 165/88, RR 22, 91% on RA. Patient initially on NRB for sats in low
   80s, and then weaned down 5L NC with sats in mid 90s. She was ruled out

   to contrast, 1mg ativan.
   Pt. has since been ruled out for MI with negative cardiac enzymes times
   3.  Negative serum tox screen.  Had echo with bubble study, final read
   pending.

This 80-year-old patient with known
aortic stenosis has been followed up with serial
echocardiograms and a recent echoes showed worsening aortic
stenosis to a critical degree and hence she was investigated
for aortic valve replacement. Preoperative coronary angiogram
showed no significant coronary artery disease and the left
ventricular function was well-preserved. Past medical history
was significant for left upper lobectomy for malignancy fears
and COPD and obesity.
FINDINGS:  The ascending aorta was normal size. There were
some atheromatous plaques in the innominate area. The
cannulation was done lower on the ascending aorta to avoid
this area. The aortic valve was heavily diseased, tricuspid,
heavily calcified with severe annular calcification. The
coronary artery ostia were in the normal location.

Epic tissue valve. [**2650-5-29**]

Mr. [**Known patient lastname 10895**] is a 69 year-old gentleman who was transferred from [**Hospital Ward Name **] for XRT for SCLC. He has HTN, Afib, DM, dysphagia and newly
   diagnosed mediastinal mass and has been suffering from one month of
   dyspnea, cough and progressive dysphagia to solids and eventually
   liquids. He had an outpatient workup including EGD on [**3034-11-3**] which
   showed a 20mm esophageal ulcer and gastritis. Biopsy of the ulcer was
   negative for cancer. GI recommended CT chest ([**3034-11-13**]), which revealed
   an 11 SI x 11 TRV x 5.6 cm AP central, posterior mediastinal mass
   impinging on the trachea and completely compressing the esophagus. On
   [**3034-11-18**], he underwent a flexible bronchoscopy, EBUS, and
   transbronchial biopsy of the mediastinal mass. Initially the pathology
   was read as inadequate tissue for diagnosis secondary to excessive
   necrotic debris but likely a small cell carcinoma. On [**3034-11-23**] he
   presented to the ED with shortness of breath, fever and hypotension and
   was admitted to the MICU for management. Initial ED VS T 102.4 HR 111
   BP 125/69 RR22 SaO2 100% RA. Was tx w/ Vanc, Levo and 3L IVF. CXR on
   admission showed that the mediastinal mass appears to have grown in
   size. Antibiotics were changed to CTX, Vanc and Azithromycin in the
   MICU. Interventional Pulmonology did a repeat flexible bronchoscopy,
   EBUS and biopsy which was non-diagnostic. Because he was dyspneic and
   unable to lie flat, he underwent rigid bronchoscopy, for which he was
   intubated. A Y-stent was placed, he had CT chest and was transferred to
   the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] so he could start XRT in the AM. In the meantime, pathology
   reviewed the tissue obtained on [**3034-11-18**] and decided that the histology
   showed poorly differentiated carcinoma with +neuroendocrine cells.

   increased shortness of breath, cough x several weeks, weakness and
   malaise. Breathing worse last night. Had ~ 1 hour SSCP last night,
   resolved spontaneously. Also had mild HA yesterday, nausea, no
   vomiting. CT to rule out head bleed complete.   Called 911 at home PM
   of [**10-27**].  EMS found pt w/ SPO2 80s. To [**Hospital 1211**] hosp where pt found in
   rapid A-fib w/ HR 120s- started on diltiazem gtt. Also T101.  Tx'd
   [**Hospital1 17**]- on arrival in [**Name (NI) 68**] pt w/ SBP 70s- dilt stopped.  IVF bolus up.
   +fevers at home so given IV levoquin and IV ceftriaxone. WBC=17. CXR
   consistent with multifocal PNA, possible heart failure as well.
   Requiring NRB mask 100% to maintain SPO2>90.
   Also of note, pt poor historian, unclear of which medications she takes
   at home. Also doesn't take certain meds b/c she has trouble swallowing
   them. Has had speech and swallow in past. (S/p CVA [**2606**]).
   Pneumonia, other
   Assessment:
   Pt arrived to CCU with 4LNC. Shortly after, O2NC uptitrated to 6L to
   keep O2sat>90 where she stayed most of day. At 1600, monitor alarmed
   for SPO2 84-88% range.  Pt w/ rr high 20s, denied SOB.  Encouraged
   C+DB. SBP also down to 76 during episode.
   + Congested cough rarely productive of yellow sputum.  Lung exam with
   diffuse rales. Elevated WBC 17. CXR consistent with mulifocal PNA as
   well as component of CHF. RR 20s. Denied difficulty breathing.
   Action:
   Given incentive spirometer and teaching on admission. Reinforced
   importance of C+DB. Notified team of O2sat &BP drop-> team in to
   evaluate. Stat CXR, ABG, albuterol and mucomyst nebs, 250ml NS bolus at
   1600. O2 switched to plain face mask, then cool mist neb per resp
   recommendation. Goal SPO2 88-92%. Not diagnosed w/ COPD, but likely has
   component from smoking hx per team.
   Response:
   SPO2 appropriately up within target range after above interventions and
   on cool mist neb @ 60% at 8LNC.  ABG 7.4/47/68/30. Lactate down to 2.4
   (3.4 on adm). CXR without significant change. Needs encouragement for
   C&DB/ incentive spirometer.
   Plan:
   Closely monitor resp status. Keep O2sat 88-92% range.  Pulm toileting/
   Chest PT. Albuterol nebs q 6 hours. Assess O2 requirements. Encourage
   C+DB, IS 10x/hour. F/U results of sputum cx.

d ceftriaxone

[**Age over 90 **] y.o. male with dementia, prior left frontotemporal CVA, atrial
   fibrillation on warfarin, COPD by radiograph who presents from nursing
   home with dyspnea and found to have multifocal pneumonia on chest
   radiograph new from prior admission 12 days ago. According to patient's
   wife, he was in his normal state of health the day prior, which is
   demented, unable to walk and or perform ADLs, but had eaten a full
   meal. He reportedly has had problems with swallowing his foods and has
   been noted to cough after eating and drinking. To the best of the
   wife's knowledge, he has not had any sick contacts. Today, he was noted
   to have a dyspnea and a low-grade fever and was thus brought in to the
   ED for further evaluation.
   .
   In the ED, initial vs were: 100.8, 124/104, 137, 28-40, 99% NRB (89%
   RA), blood pressure dipped to 78/29 at 2100 prior to transfer and
   lactate was elevated to 6.2. CXR showed multifocal PNA and patient was
   given vancomycin 1g, zosyn 4.5g, and 650mg tylenol along with 1 liter
   normal saline. After discussion with patient's wife and HCP, it was
   clarified that patient is DNR/DNI. Additionally, the patient's wife
   expressed a desire to have no central access or pressors. Given his
   dyspnea and tachypnea, BiPAP was started and the patient was more calm.
   He was admitted to the ICU for further management.
   .
   On the floor, patient appeared comfortable and denied pain. He was able
   to follow commands. The patient's wife and son were engaged in a
   lengthy conversation during which the wife revealed that she is
   confident that the patient would not want anything to prolong his life
   given his current mental status and quality of life. She and her son
   expressed a goal of keeping him comfortable with BiPAP since it had
   been started and morphine if necessary for air hunger. The wife
   eventually expressed an interest in discontinuing antibiotics since she
   felt that they were counterproductive in the goal of not prolonging his
   life. It was also decided to hold IVF.

Ms. [**Known patient lastname 2825**] is a 52yo woman h/o COPD, breast cancer who presented to an
   OSH for evaluation of shortness of breath. She notes she has not been
   feeling well for several weeks when she noted pain in her back.
   Initially she was diagnosed with a muscle spasm and given pain
   mediation. When the pain did not subside she returned for further care
   and it was noted that she had a rash that appeared to be consistant
   with shingles. She describes the pain as a band from her abdomen to her
   back. She was treated with a course of valtrex which she completed and
   the rash resolved. Her pain persisted, despite treatment with oxycodone
   and vicodin. Over the last several days, the patient noted a sore
   throat and increasing oxygen requirement (she typically is on 2L O2 NC
   at home). She also noted fevers to 102 at home and decreasing O2 sats
   from 90s to 79% with ambulation. This past weekend (during storm) the
   patient was exceedingly anxious after the electricity went out. She was
   trying to find her oxygen tank and felt herself coughing so hard she
   could barely catch her breath.
   She denies having any chest pains or dizziness, N/V. She went to an OSH
   for shortness of breath and back pain. On CXR she found to have
   multifocal PNA, also notable on labs were a leukocytosis to 24, d-dimer
   1.2 (elevated). A CTA was performed however there was dye leak into the
   left hand and the test was aborted. She was given ceftriaxone and
   transfered to [**Hospital1 1**].
   On arrival, she was noted to be afebrile with BPs in 120/60s, HR 105,
   breathing in 20s, O2 sats 80s on 2L. With albuterol and ipratropium
   nebs and morphine her O2 sat was 90s on 4L and much more comfortable.
   Noted on exam were a tense compartment in L hand. Plastics was called
   to evaluate and recommended elevatation and frequent pulse checks. CT
   from the outside hospital shows multifocal PNA, however given lack of
   contrast cannot evaluate for PE. Also on CXR were 3 fractured ribs on R
   side. Notable on her labs in the ED were a leukocytosis with left
   shift, elevated bicarb. She was started on 750mg levofloxacin IV and 1L
   IVF was started prior to transfer to the MICU. On admission to ICU, she
   was afebrile with BP 130/70s, HR 103, 95% 4L O2.
   .

   RV perforation.  The patient states that his symptoms began 3 weeks
   ago, when he began to experience chest pain with exertion.  The chest
   pain was a pressure, [**3-31**], exacerbated with exertion, which radiated to
   his left shoulder.  The pain resolved with rest.  The patient underwent
   an ETT last Tuesday, where he exercised 4-5 minutes before reproducing
   the same chest pain.  The pain continued for approximately 4 minutes of
   rest after the test was stopped.  He was started on Toprol XL and
   presented to [**Hospital6 1749**] today for elective cardiac
   catheterization.  During the catheterization, a 90% stenosis was found
   in the LAD, so the patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 17**] for PCI.
   .
   During the cardiac catheterization at [**Hospital1 17**], the patient was found to
   have a 99% stenosis in the LAD and an apical occlusion.  A wire was
   advance through the apical occlusion in order to restore flow, and
   there was a contrast stain worrisome for microperforation.  The patient
   had a TTE at this time which did not show any evidence of effusion.  He
   was thus admitted to the CCU for further observation and evaluation.

Chief Complaint:  altered mental status, ?laryngeal edema
   HPI:
   Ms. [**Hospital1 5871**] is a 59F homeless woman with DM h/o alcoholism and
   polysubstance abuse who is transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for question of
   laryngeal edema and difficulty weaning from the ventilator.
   .
   She reportedly had a recent hospitalization at [**Hospital1 470**] for housing
   placement and ?cellulitis. She was then referred to [**Hospital 622**] Healthcare
   for further care and placement in an apartment. The day of planned
   discharge [**6-23**] pt was noted to be increasingly anxious. She was given
   diazepam without improvement. She became confused. Vitals were obtained
   showing HR in 40's, BP 100/60 and "low O2" which improved to 96% on
   unknown amount of supplemental O2.
   .
   In the [**Hospital1 622**] ER, she was "somnolent" and given narcan x1 due to
   concern for narcotics overdose (she had been taking oxycontin). She
   subsequently became agitated and was intubated for airway protection.
   Admission labs were notable for acute renal failure with Cr of 2.5
   (reportedly in 1's [** Location **]usly), K of 7.4, ABG 7.28/56/379 on 3L NC
   prior to intubation. CXR showed mild pulmonary edema. CT head showed no
   CNS bleed, but evidence of an orbital floor fracture thought to be old.
   Vitals on presentation to the ICU were 98.4 P 39-42 BP 79/40-96/37 O2
   100% on AC FiO2 0.6.
   .
   She was able to wean off the ventilator rapidly. Extubation was
   attempted on [**6-25**], but within an hour she developed stridor that
   responded poorly to nebs, epinephrine, and lasix. On reintubation she
   was thought to have laryngeal edema. Seen by ENT who felt she would
   need extubation attempt in OR with setup ready for emergency crich. She
   was transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for further management given lack of 24h ENT
   coverage at [**Hospital1 622**].

   [**Hospital1 1**].  When EMS arrived she was complaining of shortness of breath.

   94% on a non-rebreather.  She was noted to have scant wheezes in her
   upper lung fields.  EKG showed sinus tachycardia, right bundle branch
   block, q waves in III, avF, TWF V1-V3.  She was taken to the emergency
   room.
   In the ED, initial vs were: T: 98.8 P: 113 BP: 130/84 R: 25 O2 sat: 85%
   on RA.   Initial CXR showed possible infiltrate in the L upper lobe.
   EKG showed sinus tachycardia, left axis, right bundle branch block, TWI
   V1-V3, q waves III, avF, no change compared to prior earlier in the
   day.  She received vancomycin 1 gram IV x 1, zosyn 4.5 grams x 1,
   combivent nebulizers x 3, solumedrol 125 mg IV x 1.  She was placed on
   BIPAP with mild improvement.  She also received nitroglycerine for
   potential volume overload as well as lasix 20 mg IV x 1.  Her BNP was
   elevated at 1122.  Her WBC was 15.1 with 91% neutrophils.  She had one
   set of negative cardiac enzymes.  She was admitted to the intensive
   care unit for further management.
   On arrival to the ICU she reports that her shortness of breath has
   improved somewhat from this morning.  She denies fevers, chills, chest
   pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, dysuria,
   hematuria, leg pain or swelling.  Comes from rehab.  Has had recent
   rhinorrhea and productive cough without fevers.  Mild diarrhea at
   rehab.  All other review of systems negative in detail.

   exam.
   Plan:

   made CMO when rest of family arrives this evening from west coast.  At
   this point pt not fitting brain death criteria but is progressing in
   that direction. NEOB following pt. and to be called if brain death
   testing will be conducted.  Support to family.

This is a [**Age over 90 **] year old female with hx recent PE/DVT, atrial
   fibrillation, CAD who is transfered from  [**Hospital3 915**] Hospital for
   ERCP. She has had multiple admissions to [**Hospital3 915**] this past month,
   most recently on [**2963-11-24**]. In early [**Month (only) 776**], she presented with back
   pain and shortness of breath. She was found to have bilateral PE's and
   new afib and started on coumadin. Her HCT dropped slightly, requiring
   blood transfusion, with guaic positive stools. She was discharged and
   returned with abdominal cramping and black stools. She was found to
   have a HCT drop from 32 to 21. She was given vit K, given a blood
   transfusion and started on protonix. She received an IVF filter and
   EGD.  EGD showed a small gastric and duodenal ulcer (healing),
   esophageal stricture, no active bleeding.  She also had an abdominal
   CT  demonstrating a distended gallbladder with gallstones and biliary
   obstruction with several CBD stones. She was started on Levo/Flagyl and
   transfered here for ERCP. Per nursing, her BP had been low in 90's at
   OSH and 80's enroute.
   .
   In the ERCP suite, she received vancomycin, Ampicillin and Gentamicin
   as well as Fentanyl. A biliary stent was placed successfully in the
   upper third of the common bile duct. No sphincterotomy was done given
   elevated INR. She was transferred here s/p procedure as she was found
   to be Hypotensive with concern for sepsis.
